Lack enough support: The claim lacks support as there is no evidence or confirmation from any reputable source that calling the phone number on the back of a baby formula product will result in receiving a free case during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the statements made by infant formula manufacturers Nestlé, Danone, A2 Milk, and US infant formula brand Enfamil, who all stated that the claim is a hoax and that they do not distribute free cases of formula.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that calling the phone number on the back of a baby formula product will lead to receiving a free case, without providing any evidence or explanation for why this would be the case.
Understate: The claim may be understating the potential consequences or risks associated with sharing personal information over the phone, especially during a time of heightened scams and fraud attempts related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim is exaggerating any aspect.
